Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I glanced at my phone at a red light, seeing a message from my stepdad: “Rough day. Can you call when you get a chance?” My heart squeezed. He rarely reached out like this, and I knew Mom had been distant lately. I wanted to pull over, call him, and ask if everything was okay at home, like I always tried to do. But the light turned green, and my passenger in the backseat cleared his throat impatiently. I gripped the wheel, reminding myself to keep my eyes on the road, obey the speed limit, and drive safely—my job depended on it. Every time my phone buzzed, I felt torn. My stepdad needed me, but I couldn’t risk a ticket or an accident. The city rolled by, my mind split between the responsibility to my family and the duty to my passenger. I wrestled with the urge to help at home and the need to be a professional behind the wheel, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me as I drove on.
